./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-010-00.wav: This book is about the unique phenomenon of long-term marriages in our society's older generation, and about the husbands and wives in those marriages who are living longer, and coping and caring for each other longer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-010-01.wav: It is estimated that almost half of this entire generation consists of husbands and wives in marriages of approximately half a century.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-010-02.wav: This amounts to about fifteen million people who are age sixty-five and over, and who are not only living longer than ever before but also living together longer than ever before.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-011-00.wav: Since these long-term marriages did not occur in the past, except in unusual or isolated cases, there has been comparatively little serious study or attention to them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-011-01.wav: A number of questions have been left unexplored or unanswered:
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-012-01.wav: What new developments or circumstances or special combinations of factors brought about such longer lasting lives and marriages?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-013.wav: What changes do the added years bring to these marriages, both to the individual husbands and wives and also to the relationships between them?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-014.wav: How do these husbands and wives cope with the changes, and how do their ongoing marital relationships shape, or become shaped by, the added years?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-015.wav: What is the cost of this gift of more time?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-016.wav: What can be learned, especially as a message to the next generation for its own marital expectations?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-017-00.wav: These are the questions this book addresses.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-017-01.wav: The book is organized into three parts, each dealing with a different aspect of long-term marriage.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-018-00.wav: Part One, Changing Times, discusses important factors directly contributing to and resulting from these lasting marriages.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-018-01.wav: The factors include the impact of human longevity on how long marriages can be and what they can be like; the effects of changes in sickness and health as people live longer and age later; and the resulting need to eventually give or receive care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-021-00.wav: Three patterns emerge from these real human experiences.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-021-01.wav: One pattern is that living longer and being married longer bring health changes that would not have occurred, and certainly would not have been shared, if the couple's lives and marriages had been briefer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-021-02.wav: The second pattern is that over time, these aging-related health changes inevitably and increasingly require care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-021-03.wav: And the third pattern is that this care is provided, as much as needed and as long as needed, by the husbands and wives for themselves and for each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-021-04.wav: Therefore, the conclusion, which is the theme and subtitle of this book From Caring to Caretaking is that long-term marriage, in one way or another, inevitably and inescapably changes the marital relationship from caring about each other to taking care of each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-022-00.wav: The material in this book is derived from three major sources.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-022-01.wav: One is professional literature about the aging process written by gerontologists, psychologists, and sociologists.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-022-02.wav: Second are observations of and interviews with the twenty-four long-married couples whose stories are told here.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-022-03.wav: And third is my own personal experience of more than a half century of marriage.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-023-00.wav: This book is dedicated to my husband, Edward Hawthorne.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-023-01.wav: We have now been together as a married couple much more than twice as long as we had been apart as separate individuals.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-023-02.wav: So by this time, we no longer know which of us is the better half; but we do know that neither one of us, without the other, would be whole.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-024-00.wav: Today's older generation is the longest lived and longest married of any in our society's history.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-024-01.wav: We know that science and technology-based longevity are what have made these long lives and marriages possible.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-024-02.wav: During the last century, almost thirty years have been added to the expected lifespan, and the possible duration of marriage has been virtually doubled.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-024-03.wav: Indeed, many of these couples have now been married forty, fifty, sixty, or even more years, which is longer than people used to live only a few generations ago!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-025-00.wav: These long-term marriages are unique to today's older generation because of the special confluence of longevity and monogamy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-025-01.wav: Longevity has made them possible, but monogamy has made them desirable.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-025-02.wav: Such long-term marriages did not occur in the last generation and may not in the next one for vastly different reasons.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-026-00.wav: In the previous generation, most men and women stayed married to each other as long as they lived, but they did not live long enough to celebrate such advanced anniversaries.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-026-01.wav: For them, the so-called silver anniversary, twenty-five years, was long-term; more was not expected and was not usual.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-027-00.wav: The shorter span of these marriages produced a kind of stability during whatever time they lasted.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-027-01.wav: Husbands and wives usually lived only into their fifties or occasionally sixties.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-027-02.wav: They worked at their jobs, raised their children, and died not long afterward.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-030-00.wav: That means they will probably not be able to celebrate wedding anniversaries of forty, fifty, or more years unless they add together the different years of their separate marriages!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-030-01.wav: Even though the baby boomers will be younger, stronger, healthier, active longer than any previous generation, they too will ultimately grow older and change with age, even if later in their lives.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-030-02.wav: And when that happens, it means that many will find themselves not in long-lasting marriages as their parents did, but merely in their last marriages.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-031-00.wav: It is only the current older generation that uniquely has both monogamy and longevity.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-031-01.wav: The previous generation experienced monogamy without longevity, and it appears that the next generation will have the reverse.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-032-00.wav: It is obvious that longevity has altered the number of years possible in people's lives and marriages, but what is less obvious is that longevity also has altered the very nature of those years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-032-01.wav: The new years added to old marriages do not bring merely more of the same.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-032-02.wav: They bring time for changes, opportunities, and problems that would not have occurred or even been possible before.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-032-03.wav: They bring new and different circumstances and they change old and expected ones.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-033-00.wav: For example, there are certain important normal developmental changes that, in the past, occurred during the final years of marriage.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-033-01.wav: These changes are the end of full-time parenting, when children grow up and go off into separate adult lives, and the end of full-time working, when men and women retire from their out-of-home jobs and careers.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-033-02.wav: In the previous generation, there were few years left in people's lifetimes after these normal developmental changes occurred.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-033-04.wav: These are years in which husbands and wives have more time in their days and their lives to be with each other without those previous familiar occupying roles.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-033-05.wav: However, it turns out that this additional time does not bring just more years to be together, but mostly more years to be old together which is both a bonus and a burden in their lives.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-035-00.wav: For today's long-lived and long-married couples, these aging-related health changes occur precisely during those years that have now been added to their marriages: the fourth, fifth, and later decades.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-035-01.wav: Indeed, the golden anniversary, fifty years, seems to form an almost irreversible threshold for age-related health problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-035-02.wav: As a result, many of these supposedly celebrating couples find themselves complaining that the so-called golden years are really rather tarnished!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-035-03.wav: In other words, the longevity that has made long-lasting marriages possible has also made the aging-related health problems inevitable.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-036-00.wav: Certainly, all husbands and wives do not experience health and aging changes in the same way or at the same time or at the same rate.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-036-01.wav: Some of these changes may be slow and minor, especially at first, and only require care that is slight and minor, also at first.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-036-02.wav: But over time, as long as life continues to be prolonged, these changes and needs will also continue and, in fact, escalate.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-036-03.wav: Inevitably even if later rather than sooner, even if gradually rather than drastically, even if only one spouse more than the other, aging-related health problems will create special needs and require special care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-037-00.wav: In addition to the personal aging changes that come with a long life, long-married couples also experience and share each other's aging changes.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-037-01.wav: So it is not only an individual's health problems that affect married life in the later years, but also the spouse's and the effect each one has on the other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-038-00.wav: The result is that health and aging become overriding presences in a long-term marriage.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-038-01.wav: They become constant sources of concern and attention, even a controlling influence affecting in some way what these couples can do, what they can have, what they can expect, and how they can feel.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-038-02.wav: Health and aging seem to take over the last years of lasting marriages, virtually redefining what husbands and wives will now need from each other and what they will need to do for each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-039-00.wav: This is neither a happy nor a sad ending for these marriages, but the price paid by these husbands and wives for the gift of time they have received.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-039-01.wav: Therefore, the only way not to eventually need any special care for oneself, or not to need to give any special care to a spouse, is not to live so long or to be married so long!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-040-00.wav: The words in sickness and in health, which are such an important part of traditional marriage vows, take on new meaning and reality for long-married couples.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-040-01.wav: Concern about sickness becomes everpresent, and being well comes to mean only being well enough.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-042-01.wav: At that time, the five leading recorded causes of death were pneumonia, tuberculosis, diarrhea, heart disease, and stroke.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-043-01.wav: Also, by this time, the five leading causes of death had changed to heart disease, cancer, stroke, respiratory disease, and accidents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-00.wav: During the twentieth century, especially the latter half, major and far-reaching changes occurred in health care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-01.wav: Certain illnesses, such as infections and intestinal diseases, were able to be prevented or almost eliminated through improved sanitation, diet, or inoculation.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-02.wav: Some illnesses, such as diabetes, were able to be mitigated through early diagnosis and treatment.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-03.wav: Others, such as heart damage and joint atrophy, were able to be corrected through surgery, implants, or replacements.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-04.wav: For strokes and other previously crippling diseases, disabling effects were able to be compensated through prostheses or orthopedic equipment.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-05.wav: Some severe illnesses, though not necessarily curable, became treatable; and in fatal diseases, death was able to be deferred through drugs or life-support systems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-045-06.wav: Finally, in surgery, though still not totally risk free, serious risks became more rare even as technical possibilities became more remarkable.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-046-01.wav: As a result, people now live long enough to develop muscular or skeletal deterioration, as in osteoporosis, or irreparable sensory loss, as in macular degeneration, or severe neurological impairment, as in Parkinson's disease, or mental health damage, as in Alzheimer's disease.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-047-01.wav: Medical experts are beginning to call cancer a disease of aging, and to predict that, with longevity, people will live into ages when cancer is more and more likely to occur.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-048-00.wav: These new medical improvements are also enabling people to recover sufficiently from certain illnesses that they would not have previously survived, and to live many years afterward, even with residual effects or disabilities.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-048-01.wav: Patients no longer necessarily die of the first heart attack or immediately after a stroke or shortly after the first diagnosis of cancer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-048-02.wav: Instead, through new treatment strategies, they may continue living, although needing and undergoing special care, and although in fragile or diminished condition.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-049-00.wav: So it is not that these older men and women suffer less illness because they are living longer; but they are suffering different kinds of illnesses and living with them longer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-049-01.wav: This means that they are suffering more from chronic than acute health conditions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-049-02.wav: Research studies have shown that three fourths of all people over age seventy-five have at least one, and usually more, chronic health problems of some kind or degree.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-049-03.wav: Since they are chronic, by definition they do not get better over time; they get gradually and inexorably worse.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-050-00.wav: Even though the human lifespan has increased and general fitness has improved so markedly during the past century, no one can be young and well forever.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-050-01.wav: The human body was not designed to last indefinitely nor, after some years of use, to function flawlessly.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-050-02.wav: There is no escaping the process of aging, which causes wear and tear on older bodies, which then lose their capacity to cope with illness or injury.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-050-03.wav: In other words, no matter how long or how well life is extended, ultimately it must reach a functioning limit that is foreshadowed by the onset of aging.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-050-04.wav: Noted gerontologist doctor Caleb Finch summed up by saying, Aging is an inevitable result of living, just as death is an inevitable consequence of life.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-051-00.wav: Husbands and wives both inevitably age as they live long enough, but their aging is not necessarily the same, due to individual differences and also to gender differences.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-051-01.wav: The demographics of today's older generation clearly indicate a preponderance of women, and not only are there more women than men, but they are also living longer than men.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-051-02.wav: As a result, it has been observed that adulthood, which was a world of ruling men, has now been succeeded by old age, which is a world of surviving women!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-052-00.wav: Such disparate experts as gerontologist doctor Robert Butler, psychoanalyst Erik Erikson, and feminist Betty Friedan have all agreed that women are aging better than men, defined in terms of functioning as well as longevity.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-052-01.wav: Research has shown that, with the exception of Alzheimer's disease, all of today's leading medical killers take a greater toll on older men than on older women.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-052-02.wav: In addition, women not only live longer, but also seem to retain physical and mental skills longer and stronger.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-053-00.wav: There are a number of examples and possible explanations for this.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-053-01.wav: One is that men seem to seek medical care less promptly, and are more impatient and less satisfied with that care when they receive it.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-053-02.wav: Also, aging men have more difficulty dealing with physical changes, especially those related to signs of weakness or impotence.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-053-03.wav: Perhaps because so much of their self-image and self-esteem is connected to their sense of strength and power, they see doctors later or less, since to do otherwise would be to acknowledge weakness.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-053-04.wav: In addition, it is extremely difficult for men to accept chronic health conditions; they do better in situations of acute illness, which, though sometimes more drastic, may still offer the possibility of a solution or a quick fix or a chance of change.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-054-00.wav: Men are also particularly unlikely to have emotional or social supports outside of their families, specifically their wives, or even to seek those supports when they suffer illness.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-054-01.wav: In fact, the acknowledgment of any need for emotional help may be even more difficult for men than acknowledging the need for medical help because it seems more damaging to self-esteem.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-055-00.wav: On the other hand, women may be able to turn to doctors more regularly and easily because, as mothers, they have been accustomed to taking care of the health needs of their children and families over the years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-055-02.wav: Furthermore, since women have been accustomed to providing emotional support in their roles as family nurturers, they are more able and willing to seek emotional support for themselves when they feel it may be needed or helpful.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-055-03.wav: In other words, women seek doctors or other kinds of resources more than men do and for more health problems, and men die younger.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-056-00.wav: There have also been a number of illuminating research studies about health and aging and about gender and aging.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-056-01.wav: One recent medical finding is that for older men, there seems to be a correlation between the emergence of health problems and permanent retirement from life work or profession.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-056-02.wav: So it may be that while men are still feeling in a positive role as wage earners and producers, and receiving gratification from this, they may be more able to mask or deny or sublimate health symptoms.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-060-00.wav: Today's grown sons or daughters do not care less about their aging parents.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-061-00.wav: It was not that in the past some kind of caretaking was never needed, but the older generation did not usually live long enough to require it for long.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-061-01.wav: If elderly parents did need assistance, this was invariably provided by dutiful children, especially daughters.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-064-00.wav: There is another difference between caretaking then and now.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-064-01.wav: Before the days of women's independent work or careers, daughters were usually available as homemakers.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-066-01.wav: In contrast, today's older people need both more and less care than in the previous generation.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-067-00.wav: Still another important reason for the change in caretaking responsibility is that today's older generation has long taught and sought independence, both for themselves and for their children.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-069-00.wav: The need to take care, or to be taken care of, in the later years of lasting marriages may be inevitable, but how the need is met is far from the same in all situations.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-072-00.wav: Among these long-married caretaking couples, four patterns can be discerned, each with its own special arrangements, expectations, possibilities, and challenges, and also each with its own experiences and stories.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-074-00.wav: In some ways, wives who take care of their husbands may find it easier than how husbands experience taking care of their wives.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-00.wav: Love demands sacrifice, and love binds us.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-01.wav: Our attachments to those we love constrict us as much as they anchor us.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-02.wav: Our parents bound themselves in sacrifice to us when we were young; the Fifth Commandment says we should bind ourselves in allegiance to them when they are old.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-03.wav: Children see their worth in their parents eyes while they are growing up; parents see their worth in their children's eyes as they themselves age.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-04.wav: We care for our children when they are young.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-05.wav: We hope our children will care for us when we become old.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-085-06.wav: And so it indeed goes if all goes well.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-086-00.wav: At the end, parents may need their children to sacrifice their lives for them for a time, despite the hardships that their need imposes on them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-086-01.wav: Parents may recognize that the ties between them and their children now bind too tightly.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-086-02.wav: When we were young, our parents held us, locked eyes with us, and gave us what they could, hoping to make good lives for us.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-087-02.wav: While he may long for freedom, the child stays silent, knowing the parent could experience that longing as a wish for his hasty death.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-087-03.wav: For a parent to believe that his child feels this way is too much to bear and too much to acknowledge.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-088-00.wav: This fourth group consists of younger older couples, in their late sixties or early to mid-seventies, who are still in the early stages of their aging process.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-090-00.wav: Different couples react in many different ways to these beginning signs of aging.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-090-01.wav: Some simply continue doing whatever they want to do or have always done, not making any changes in their lives or lifestyles whether due to denial or bravado or sheer optimism.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-090-02.wav: Some, willingly or reluctantly, accept the need for some changes but try to keep the changes as limited and unobtrusive as possible.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-092-00.wav: Sunny and Everett met shortly after World War two in a teacher training program.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-092-01.wav: Sunny was studying to be a kindergarten teacher, and Everett was enrolled under the G I bill to become a physical education teacher.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-093-00.wav: They both remember those years as being the best of all possible worlds.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-093-01.wav: He enjoyed working with the boys, teaching and coaching sports; she enjoyed teaching little children and then later on, staying at home to raise their own two children.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-094-00.wav: The income from teaching was not luxurious, but it was sufficient.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-094-01.wav: There was always time for family summer vacations, though major plans for extended travel had to be reserved until after the children were grown or after retirement.
