./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-095-02.wav: He was hospitalized for a week and was diagnosed as having moderate to severe arterial blockages.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-095-03.wav: Then he recuperated for several more weeks at home with instructions for diet, medication, therapy, and rest.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-096-00.wav: At first, Everett was great, seemingly undaunted and unafraid, even telling amusing stories about his hospital experiences.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-096-02.wav: There were occasional chest pains and recurrent fatigue.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-096-03.wav: a few years ago, and about two years after the original diagnosis, the cardiologist recommended bypass surgery, not as an emergency but as a preventive measure against future heart attacks.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-097-01.wav: But this time his reaction was very different.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-097-03.wav: Sunny watched over him and tried not to upset him with any arguments or disagreements.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-098-00.wav: Now whenever Sunny goes anywhere, Everett insists that she tell him how he can reach her, just in case.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-098-01.wav: Before going to sleep at night, he makes certain she remembers exactly where his emergency medication is, just in case.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-098-02.wav: And he has repeatedly reviewed with her all their important documents, again just in case.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-099-00.wav: His anxiety has become so contagious that their children have even broached the possibility of their parents moving closer, just in case.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-099-01.wav: At the same time they warn Sunny not to hover over Everett so much, saying that it's not good for either of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-101-00.wav: Lina and Jess recently celebrated their fiftieth anniversary.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-101-01.wav: It was a quiet event because they have no children or nearby family, and also for health reasons.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-105-00.wav: A few years ago, Jess began to complain about fatigue, shortness of breath, and unusual swellings in his legs that affected his walking.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-105-01.wav: Doctors visits and tests concluded with a diagnosis of beginning congestive heart failure.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-105-02.wav: Jess was treated with diuretic medication, a fluid-restricted diet, and limited physical activity.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-105-03.wav: The doctors made it clear that this was a condition that would continue and possibly worsen over time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-106-00.wav: Over the past two years, Jess has had to be briefly hospitalized twice for what the couple calls drying out times, because his body was accumulating fluids.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-106-01.wav: When he came home after each of these episodes, he seemed a little more tired than before, as if moving on a gradual downward spiral.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-109-00.wav: They have no way of knowing when the next drying out time will occur, because there are no special advance warnings.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-109-01.wav: They don't even talk about it much, though they certainly think about it and know it will happen.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-110.wav: Meanwhile, Lina tells Jess that he is such a good patient, to which Jess usually replies, That's because I have someone who takes such good care of me!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-111-00.wav: Celia and Sam have been married sixty-four years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-111-01.wav: They have known each other since childhood, and their parents also knew each other, so somehow it was always assumed that they would marry when they grew up which they did.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-111-03.wav: And Sam adds, with a dry humor he has been able to preserve, Our marriage is almost old enough now to collect social security!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-112-00.wav: They both come from traditional homes, and that became the pattern of their own marriage and family life.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-112-01.wav: Sam owned and operated a bakery shop in the neighborhood.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-112-02.wav: Celia stayed home to raise their four children, to keep their home immaculate and orderly, and to cook the special foods her family enjoyed.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-112-03.wav: All of these were things she enjoyed doing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-112-04.wav: She says she never had any desire for independence or any interest in outside work as her own adult daughters and especially her granddaughters seem to have.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-113-00.wav: Celia was not even interested in learning how to drive.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-113-01.wav: She did so at Sam's insistence, but she still feels uncomfortable behind the wheel.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-113-02.wav: She was also never good with numbers, so she was pleased and relieved that Sam took responsibility for all their business and financial matters.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-113-03.wav: She never felt a need to know any of the details because she trusted Sam's decisions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-114-00.wav: It was at the time of their sixtieth anniversary that Sam started experiencing severe and persistent vision problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-114-01.wav: The first treatment was cataract surgery, but his vision actually worsened afterward instead of improving.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-115.wav: Then, after consultations with specialists and various treatments that were all ineffective, the final diagnosis was macular degeneration, a progressive and incurable loss of central vision.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-117-00.wav: Celia must provide daily personal help: selecting clothes, fastening buttons and buckles, cutting and arranging food so Sam can eat unassisted.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-117-01.wav: Although her nervousness about driving has never abated, she must do all the driving for doctors visits, errands, and other activities.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-118-00.wav: Celia has also had to take responsibility for all the family paperwork, record keeping, and correspondence.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-118-01.wav: Sam works closely with her in these tasks, instructing and supervising what she has to do and write down, but she is still nervous and fearful of making mistakes.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-118-02.wav: She describes their arrangement in the following way, I'm the eyes but he's still the brains!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-119.wav: Celia feels overwhelmed sometimes because there is so much for her to do.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-121-00.wav: Their children and grown-up grandchildren are all caring and concerned but busy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-121-01.wav: They call and visit when they can and do what they can, but Celia feels that Sam is her husband and therefore her responsibility.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-122-00.wav: The first thing you notice about Betty and Ralph is how much they look alike, both of them short, stocky, round faced.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-123-00.wav: But there is a noticeable difference in their interactions with others in public due to Ralph's severe hearing loss.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-123-01.wav: Betty interprets when others speak to him, and she also speaks for him to others.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-123-02.wav: When she does, he watches her closely and nods as if, although he may not always hear what she actually says, he knows she will be saying the right things to him and for him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-124-00.wav: They were married during the late depression years, so they could not afford to go to college themselves.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-124-01.wav: Instead, by working and saving carefully, they made certain that their children could.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-124-02.wav: Now they are extremely proud of their daughter, who is a teacher, and their son, who is a doctor.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-125-00.wav: Ralph worked in retail sales and did reasonably well because he had such a friendly, pleasing way with people.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-125-01.wav: Betty worked for a while as a bookkeeper, only to earn extra income for their children's college educations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-125-02.wav: She did not particularly enjoy the work but accepted it as temporarily necessary.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-126-00.wav: As soon as their children grew up and were professionally independent, Ralph and Betty felt they could retire.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-126-01.wav: They knew their own material needs were not excessive, and they wanted to have time to do some other things.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-126-02.wav: Ralph wanted to volunteer in political organizations, and Betty wanted to help in charitable organizations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-127-00.wav: About ten years ago, Ralph started complaining about hearing loss.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-127-01.wav: At first, neither of them was concerned because they assumed it was a normal part of the aging process.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-127-02.wav: They knew that young people spoke too fast, that old people mumbled too much, and that both young and old didn't pronounce words clearly enough.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-127-03.wav: So they treated the problem with mostly good natured acceptance.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-128-00.wav: But, after a while, it became clear that Ralph's hearing loss was more severe than normal.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-128-01.wav: He was missing words and misunderstanding conversations and making mistakes because he misheard instructions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-128-02.wav: His first reaction was to begin withdrawing from social interactions with others.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-128-03.wav: Betty and their two children insisted that he consult various hearing specialists.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-129-00.wav: He was finally told that his hearing loss was due to a nerve conduction problem that was not amenable to conventional hearing aids.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-129-03.wav: It was inconvenient and intrusive and visible, and so he frequently forgot to carry it with him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-130-00.wav: Both Ralph and Betty have both decided that they are too old to learn sign language.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-130-01.wav: When they're home alone together, as they are a great deal now, they know each other well enough to communicate through looks and gestures.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-130-02.wav: Betty now takes care of their personal verbal interactions with salespeople, repair people, service providers, doctors, and so on.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-130-03.wav: She is afraid to let Ralph drive by himself, in spite of his being such a good driver, because he might not be able to hear warning signals; so she either drives him wherever he needs to go or accompanies him if he drives.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-132-00.wav: Kay and Nathan have been married forty-five years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-132-01.wav: They were both past thirty years old when they married, which was unusual in their generation when most, especially women, anticipated early matrimony.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-133-00.wav: She became interested in nature and outdoor activities, and met Nathan on a camping trip.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-133-01.wav: Like her, he was shy and quiet, enjoyed outdoor life, and was not too adept at idle social conversations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-133-02.wav: When they met, they found an immediate compatibility.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-133-03.wav: And when they decided to marry after a brief courtship, their friends and relatives were surprised, delighted, and relieved, admitting that they had virtually given up on both of them as far as marriage was concerned.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-134-00.wav: Nathan worked as a draftsman in a construction firm, and Kay had a secretarial job in a publishing house.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-134-01.wav: As soon as they could afford it, they bought a house in the country, both of them willing to accept longer commutes to their jobs to enjoy the rural setting.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-135-00.wav: When their daughter, and only child, was born, Kay decided to stay home, explaining that she had not waited so long to become a mother not to raise her child herself.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-135-01.wav: It turned out that she was actually surprised by how much she enjoyed being a stay-at-home mother and having time to become more involved in the local affairs of their small suburban community.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-00.wav: It was only five years ago, when Nathan underwent a routine medical examination, that the first signs of his prostate cancer were discovered.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-02.wav: At first, the reports were not disturbing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-03.wav: Approximately half of all men Nathan's age have some prostate cancer cells, which are usually slow growing and not necessarily life threatening.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-04.wav: They did require treatment, and Nathan's medical care started out with periodic examinations and blood tests.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-05.wav: Then, after two years, he needed injections and radiation treatments, and then finally surgery.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-136-06.wav: After each level of treatment, the cancer seemed to worsen rather than improve or stabilize.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-137-00.wav: This meant frequent trips to the doctor and the hospital, both a distance away.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-137-01.wav: Also, as the treatments intensified, Nathan grew weaker and Kay had to take over more and more of the household maintenance and transportation responsibilities, in addition to Nathan's basic physical care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-138-00.wav: By this time, their daughter urged them to sell their home in the country and move into a smaller apartment in town that would be closer to medical resources and closer to her, and would require less work and less expense.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-138-01.wav: Kay and Nathan discussed this, and finally and reluctantly agreed that it was now necessary even though it meant giving up the home that had been their family center all those years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-139-00.wav: Since Nathan was too weak to help much, Kay had to take care of most of the moving arrangements, financial arrangements, and medical care arrangements.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-139-01.wav: The new apartment is small, but it does have a patch of garden where they have planted some flowers, and they can enjoy sitting outdoors and viewing the greenery.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-139-02.wav: It is certainly more convenient in many ways, and Kay is relieved that she is closer to her daughter and can call on her for help, though she does not want to impose.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-139-03.wav: Right now she feels that she has lost her long-time home, her old friends and familiar places, and the life she used to have, and will soon lose the husband she used to have.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-00.wav: Rina and Sandy, now married fifty-two years, might well be considered the odd couple because they are so different in almost every way.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-01.wav: She is small, wiry, and sharp featured.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-02.wav: He is tall and, despite his illness and severe weight loss, still broad shouldered and broad boned, with light hair and coloring that gave him his nickname, Sandy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-03.wav: Rina is sharp tongued, with an intense, edgy quality about her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-04.wav: She prefers being busy, especially doing things that are challenging or competitive.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-140-05.wav: Sandy, on the other hand, and now when he feels well enough, has always preferred socializing with people, joking, and sharing stories.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-141-00.wav: They have two children: a son who looks like his father but is more like his mother, and a daughter who looks like her mother but is more like her father.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-141-01.wav: Rina and Sandy laugh about this, and conclude jokingly that they must have agreed with each other at least twice in their married life!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-141-02.wav: Otherwise, they acknowledge that they have disagreed about almost everything else politics, books, movies, food, people.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-141-03.wav: They still bicker and disagree even now, but it seems to be almost a ritualized pattern, without rancor.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-142-00.wav: It was just two years ago, at the age of seventy-eight, that Sandy began to complain of a surprising loss of appetite, loss of weight, and loss of energy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-142-01.wav: However, since he had no pain or fever or sign of infection, they assumed it was something temporary or just aging.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-142-02.wav: Yet the symptoms persisted and even worsened slightly, until Rina's insistence and impatience drove Sandy finally to see a doctor.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-142-03.wav: The first blood tests disclosed some anomalies, but x-raying and other examinations showed no clear causes.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-143-01.wav: Sandy was referred to other doctors and specialists of increasing reputation and also cost, and finally to a teaching hospital affiliated with a major university.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-143-03.wav: There were some experimental procedures available, but these were not advisable for Sandy because of his age.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-144-00.wav: The only recommended treatment consisted of weekly blood test monitoring, diet supplements to augment strength and appetite, and periodic blood transfusions, gradually increasing in frequency as symptoms warranted.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-144-01.wav: There was never, and still is not, any great pain, only increasing tiredness and weakness.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-145-01.wav: Rina describes it as living a double life, one up and one down.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-145-02.wav: During the down times, Sandy is almost immobilized.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-145-04.wav: Rina has gradually been taking over more of the tasks, even during the up times, and certainly during the downs.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-146-00.wav: When they are with friends, which is only during the up periods, Sandy continues to be his relaxed, charming self, pleasant and uncomplaining.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-146-01.wav: In fact, their friends are all amazed and admiring about his serenity and courage.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-146-02.wav: However, when he is home alone with Rina, he is depressed, even despairing, and is focused only on his illness and his treatments.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-148-00.wav: Margie and Jerry were high school sweethearts.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-148-01.wav: They were married right after graduation.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-149-00.wav: For Margie, you can still see the resemblance between the now tired-looking, gray-haired woman and the petite, pretty girl in the picture.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-149-01.wav: But for Jerry, there is little similarity between the broad shouldered, brawny young man in the picture and the old man now slumped in a wheelchair.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-150-00.wav: Almost ten years ago, during the period of one week, Jerry suffered first a series of minor strokes and then a major stroke from which he was initially not even expected to survive.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-150-01.wav: He did recover, but the damage from the stroke was extensive and permanent.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-150-02.wav: He lost the use of his legs and control of his lower body; his vision and speech were impaired; even the muscles of his broad shoulders and his neck and arms lost strength.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-151-00.wav: At first, Margie tried to take care of Jerry by herself, dressing, bathing, and feeding him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-151-02.wav: It was not that she was unwilling, she explains, but she simply could not manage physically.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-151-03.wav: She has now learned, with some effort, to handle the mechanics of his wheelchair, and to get him in and out of the car.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-151-04.wav: She tries to take him with her as much as possible to stores, visits, meetings and until recently he seemed to enjoy these.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-152-00.wav: Jerry's speech is quite slurred and sometimes difficult to understand, so he has become increasingly silent, especially with company.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-152-01.wav: Instead, he seems to listen intently whenever Margie says anything and, with his eyes glued on her face, he occasionally nods in agreement or understanding.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-00.wav: Margie is no longer so worried about the requirements of his physical care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-01.wav: Hard as those requirements are, she feels she is managing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-02.wav: She is concerned now about the costs of increasing and ongoing care, though she never mentions this in Jerry's presence.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-03.wav: During the years of their marriage, Jerry held a number of jobs, none of them very lucrative or lasting.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-04.wav: It wasn't that they suffered any real deprivation they managed to raise and educate two children and were always content with whatever they had but they knew they could not afford to be careless or extravagant.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-153-05.wav: Both of their children have offered Margie some financial help whenever needed, and she has assured them that so far it is not necessary, but she is grateful for the offers.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-154-00.wav: In fact, what Margie is the most worried about now, more than either physical or financial needs, is Jerry's emotional state.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-154-01.wav: He has become very despondent, even crying sometimes, and other times lapsing into long silences and unreachable withdrawals.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-154-02.wav: When their children come to visit, he scarcely speaks to them or acknowledges them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-154-03.wav: The only time he responds with any trace of pleasure is when the little two-year-old great-granddaughter is nearby.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-00.wav: One time recently, when they were alone, Jerry told Margie that she would be better off without him, that it would be better for both of them if he were dead.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-01.wav: He has repeated this several times since then, and Margie is struggling with how to respond.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-02.wav: Sometimes she pretends she didn't hear it because she doesn't know what to say.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-03.wav: Sometimes she tries to offer sympathy or reassurance, telling him things aren't really so bad and they still have each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-04.wav: Sometimes she's stern with him, admonishing that being so negative doesn't help either of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-06.wav: But nothing seems to have much effect.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-07.wav: I wish I knew what's the right thing to do or say, Margie wonders out loud.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-08.wav: I don't even know any more.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-155-09.wav: I wish someone could tell me, could help me.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-156-00.wav: Lucy and Jeff were a World War two romance, and how they met is indeed romantic.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-156-01.wav: They met at a serviceman's dance where she was one of the young local college girl hostesses and he was a brand new commissioned officer on leave.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-156-02.wav: She recalls how handsome he looked in his uniform.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-156-03.wav: Then she says, Sometimes I wonder whether that's what I fell in love with.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-156-04.wav: Maybe if it wasn't for the uniform and the war going on, maybe if we'd had more time, we might not have married each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-157-00.wav: Not that it has been an unhappy marriage, she insists, just not an easy one.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-157-01.wav: There have been repeated complaints and small unresolved quarrels that started way back when Lucy became pregnant soon into the marriage and quit college.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-157-02.wav: She never went back to school, even later on when both of their sons were older, and she thinks that Jeff's criticisms grew out of what he saw as her lack of ambition.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-159-00.wav: Then, about five years ago, Jeff suffered a massive stroke, which the doctor said was almost no surprise given his high blood pressure and excitable temperament.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-159-01.wav: The impact of the stroke was physical not mental; his mind, speech, memory, and senses all remained intact, but the right side of his body was seriously damaged.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-159-02.wav: His right arm became numb; he couldn't move or control the fingers of his right hand; his right leg sagged or dragged when he tried to stand or walk.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-160-01.wav: Lucy recalls his efforts with a combination of admiration and pity.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-160-02.wav: There was some slight improvement during the first year, but after that the improvements stopped, though his efforts did not.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-160-03.wav: At this time, Jeff uses double crutches to walk but adamantly refuses a wheelchair even when he is tired.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-160-04.wav: He has taught himself to use his left hand for some things: eating, writing, washing, dressing though these activities are difficult and slow.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-161-00.wav: Lucy describes herself as feeling torn between trying to assist him when he has difficulty or leaving him alone to struggle and perhaps succeed or fail.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-161-01.wav: Either way, she says, there are problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-161-02.wav: If she tries to do things for him, he is angry and impatient with her for being slow or clumsy; but if she doesn't try, he becomes angry at his own weakness and helplessness, and lashes out at her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-161-03.wav: So she feels torn between pity and anger, and she is never sure about the right thing to do.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-163-00.wav: Privately she complains, I know he's angry about what happened to him, and I don't blame him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-163-01.wav: But why is he angry at me?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-163-02.wav: I didn't do it to him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-164-00.wav: Linda and Alan have been married for sixty-two years, most of them, she declares emphatically, very good!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-164-01.wav: They always had a lot in common.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-164-02.wav: They shared interests in art and music, tastes in food and wine, opinions on politics, and they had similar low-key personal styles.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-165-00.wav: When Alan returned from service in World War two, they started their family.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-165-01.wav: Now their two children, four grandchildren, and two little great-grandchildren are all sources of joy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-165-02.wav: They also worked together in a small, successful home decorating business.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-165-03.wav: He took care of the finances and purchasing while she took care of the designs and customer relations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-165-04.wav: So they looked forward to enjoying a comfortable retirement when they sold their business.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-167-00.wav: Neurological tests revealed the beginning of Parkinson's disease.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-167-01.wav: The doctor prescribed medication in the form of occasional tranquilizers to be taken as needed, but warned that the illness would get worse over time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-167-02.wav: It could end up affecting his legs as well as his hands, and could diminish normal movement.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-167-03.wav: The neurologist called the disease a beast that grows fiercer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-168-00.wav: Still another blow was yet to fall.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-168-01.wav: Three years ago, Alan started forgetting things, such as instructions or requests or messages.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-168-02.wav: He had difficulty with computations, even adding or subtracting; and sometimes he didn't recognize people or places he knew.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-168-03.wav: The neurologist explained that it was not unusual for Parkinson's disease, as it worsened, to affect memory and comprehension and that all of these would be progressive.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-168-04.wav: Linda still remembers the rage she felt about that second prognosis.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-169-00.wav: By this time, the shock and anger have subsided into a routine for the two of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-169-01.wav: Linda takes responsibility for all the driving, shopping, budgeting, and domestic chores plus the occasional social activities with family members and a few close friends.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-169-02.wav: Out of years of habit, she still tries to discuss things with Alan or ask his opinions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-169-03.wav: He accepts whatever she suggests with a gentle smile, but she really isn't certain how much he understands.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-170-00.wav: She is reluctant to leave him alone anymore, even at home, because she worries that he might not remember to eat or take his medication.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-170-01.wav: Sometimes friends or family members visit or baby-sit so she can get out to do some things for herself and by herself.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-170-02.wav: She has learned to savor the late night hours, after Alan has gone to sleep, when she can be relaxed and alone to read or just think; she calls this my time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-171-00.wav: Linda is grateful that Alan is not suffering any apparent pain, and that he has not experienced any stark personality or mood changes, which the neurologist had warned might happen.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-171-01.wav: In fact, he seems to be simply more of what he always was: gentle, kind, and agreeable.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-172-00.wav: It helps, she has found, to remember all the good times and the good years, and she points out that there were a lot of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-172-02.wav: What I hope is that it will happen slowly and take so long that neither one of us will live that long.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-173-00.wav: Martha and Stan's long-term marriage has not turned out to be what either of them first wanted or expected, but Martha is someone who prides herself on facing reality rather than indulging in reminiscences or regrets.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-173-01.wav: Probably what first changed their marriage was that they did not, or could not, have children even though they hoped and tried for several years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-173-02.wav: In those days, she points out, there weren't all those medical procedures like they have now for infertility.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-173-03.wav: There was only adoption, and neither one of us wanted to raise someone else's child if we couldn't have our own.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-174-00.wav: After that, they both seemed to redirect their lives in different ways.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-174-01.wav: Stan invested with business partners in a company that manufactured women's fashions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-174-03.wav: The more he worked, the more the business prospered, and the more it prospered, the more he worked.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-174-04.wav: The successful business was what afforded them their attractive home and elegant possessions, but they got to spend very little time together.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-175-00.wav: Martha became involved in various civic, cultural, and philanthropic community organizations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-175-01.wav: She also found herself, as an only child, responsible for her widowed, ailing mother, who eventually had to be placed in a nursing home.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-175-02.wav: In addition, since Stan was so occupied in his business, Martha began taking brief vacations by herself, and to her surprise, she found herself enjoying them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-176-00.wav: Five years ago, at the time of his seventy-fifth birthday, Stan decided it was time to retire so that the two of them could finally have some time together.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-176-01.wav: He called it his birthday present to himself, but it was shortly afterward that the symptoms began.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-177-02.wav: Also, since he had always been so quiet anyway, these behaviors did not seem so unusual as to be alarming.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-178-00.wav: However, there were two drastic, cautionary incidents that changed things.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-178-01.wav: In the first one, Stan could not remember where he had parked his car, and Martha had to be summoned to find it for him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-178-02.wav: The second time, Stan became confused and lost while driving home from a place he had journeyed to and from many times.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-178-03.wav: This time, the police were involved, and again Martha had to be called.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-179-00.wav: As a result of these incidents, Martha took two immediate actions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-179-01.wav: First, she insisted that Stan promptly see a doctor even though he protested that he was really all right, only tired.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-179-02.wav: And second, she confiscated his car keys, and told him he was not ready to drive by himself for a while.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-180-00.wav: When Stan was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, Martha was not shocked because it was what she had come to suspect and fear.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-180-01.wav: Since then, the symptoms have gradually but perceptibly worsened.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-180-02.wav: Sometimes Stan forgets how to use simple utensils and has to be fed or helped to eat; a few times he has wandered out of the house and fortunately was found by neighbors who brought him home safely; and sometimes he doesn't even recognize Martha and insists that she's someone else.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-181-00.wav: At this time, Martha has made arrangements for an attendant to take care of Stan every morning; bathing, dressing, and feeding him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-181-01.wav: This gives her some time just for herself without pressure of responsibility.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-181-02.wav: There's no sense in being a martyr, Martha explains.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-181-03.wav: I have to take care of myself if I'm going to be able to take care of him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-182-00.wav: She also admits that she doesn't know how long they will be able to manage this way.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-182-02.wav: In fact, she speaks about when it may happen, not if.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-182-04.wav: I'll do whatever I have to.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-182-05.wav: And then she adds, I always have.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-183-00.wav: Nell and Martin met shortly before the end of World War two while he was still in the service.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-183-01.wav: He was assigned to a special training program that was located on the campus of a small college where she was a freshman student.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-183-03.wav: All the guys were after her, and I was the lucky one she picked.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-183-04.wav: It was clear that this was a familiar and pleasing family story.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-183-05.wav: Indeed, there is still something of the pretty young girl about Nell; her features are attractive, her figure is slim, her smile is youthful.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-184-00.wav: They were married shortly after the war ended.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-184-01.wav: Nell never completed college, preferring to stay home to be a full-time wife and then a full-time mother when their twin sons were born.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-184-02.wav: The boys were healthy and active, and Nell says appreciatively that she would never have been able to handle them without Martin's help.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-184-03.wav: Working as a real estate salesman, Martin was able to arrange his schedule and appointments to be available to help Nell at home as much as possible.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-184-04.wav: Later, when the boys were older, he expanded his schedule to work more hours, but he still tried to be available.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-185-00.wav: Nell refers to her sons, and even to Martin, as her boys.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-185-01.wav: The sons, of course, are grown men now, with homes and families of their own.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-185-02.wav: They have remained close to their parents, living nearby and celebrating all the special occasions together, such as birthdays, anniversaries, and graduations.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-187-00.wav: Nell describes herself as an obedient patient, probably because she was too numb to think about doing otherwise.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-187-02.wav: Martin assists her with many household tasks, monitors her to make certain she doesn't do too much, and makes sure that she takes her medication regularly.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-187-03.wav: The sons and their wives visit frequently and follow her progress closely.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-188-01.wav: But now Martin has no desire for socializing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-188-02.wav: He has none of Nell's social skills, and he also knows that even visiting or entertaining can be tiring for her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-188-03.wav: Instead, he has found it easier and safer for them just to draw more closely together into their own little family circle.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-189-00.wav: During the first year after the surgery, Nell tried joining a cancer survivors group but found it too depressing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-189-01.wav: All they wanted to talk about was being sick and being sad, and I didn't want that!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-190-00.wav: The doctor has told them that five years is an important landmark in breast cancer recovery, and that the odds of long-term survival improve considerably after that.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-190-01.wav: Nell is not quite there yet, and feels she is still on what she calls probation.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-190-02.wav: But recently, as they approach the end of that five-year period, she has begun talking about buying herself new clothes.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-190-03.wav: Martin is very pleased and relieved by this because, up till now, she has been unwilling to make any plans or even any purchases for the future.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-191.wav: Edith and Jack first met almost fifty years ago on a blind date, and now she points out the irony of what has happened since then to her vision.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-192-01.wav: Of course, that meant they were never able to see the beginning of any movie!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-195-00.wav: Edith and Jack have gone to the best eye doctors in the best eye clinics, and they have consulted counselors at the Braille Institute.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-195-01.wav: They have received support and suggestions but no hope.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-198-00.wav: Since that time, Jack has tried his hand at the cooking, but he readily agrees that nothing comes out right or tastes right.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-198-01.wav: They have tried to eat meals out or to bring in take-out food, but these solutions have turned out to be expensive and inconvenient.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-198-02.wav: Finally, Jack has suggested hiring someone just for a few hours each week to do the cooking but to Edith this is the most intolerable option of all.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-198-03.wav: It is not the loss of privacy that upsets her so much as it is the pain of seeing a stranger take over her role in her kitchen in her home.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-199-00.wav: So it has become increasingly difficult for both of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-199-01.wav: No matter how much or how hard Jack tries to do things, Edith is never really pleased.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-199-02.wav: And no matter how much or how hard she tries to appreciate what he does, she can never really lessen her despair.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-200-00.wav: The only solution Edith sees now is for them to move into an assisted living facility where all the necessary household services will be provided without struggle or inconvenience or constant reminder of disability.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-200-01.wav: She is convinced that she would be less unhappy in such an arrangement, and also that it would be better for Jack as well because he would have less responsibility, less pressure or work, and less need to worry about her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-202-01.wav: So meanwhile, Edith and Jack still disagree, still feel frustrated and upset, and both seem to be almost waiting for something to happen that will somehow change one of them or the other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-203-00.wav: For Lily and Herb, their long-term marriage actually started out as a long-distance one.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-203-01.wav: They were married midway during World War two, when he came home on furlough before being sent overseas.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-203-02.wav: They didn't see each other again for almost two years, when the war ended and he came home.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-204-00.wav: During the time they were apart, Lily gave birth to their son and then she went to live with her mother, who took care of the baby while Lily worked in a defense plant.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-204-01.wav: This was the beginning of a pattern of separateness that lasted most of their married life, until just a few years ago.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-205-00.wav: After the war, they continued the same living and working arrangements so that Herb could complete his college degree in economics, which he had begun before going into the service.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-205-01.wav: He did so well that he was offered a job in a prestigious and well-paying accounting firm.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-205-02.wav: After a while, Lily quit working, and they moved into their own independent place, first a small apartment, then a small house, and finally a large house.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-206-00.wav: However, Herb's job occupied him fully, including evenings and weekends when he often worked late in the office or in the small office he created for himself at home.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-206-01.wav: Sometimes he had to travel for extended periods on behalf of his company, leaving Lily feeling once again like a single parent.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-206-02.wav: She tried going with him on some of these business trips but found that she was left alone so much, while the men were preoccupied with meetings and discussions, that she decided it was easier for her to be alone at home than in these strange places.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-207-00.wav: Herb encouraged her to develop and pursue her own interests and activities.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-207-01.wav: He taught her how to drive and bought her a car.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-207-02.wav: He encouraged her to have women friends, to join clubs, to attend social or cultural events, to take classes but always without him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-207-03.wav: He himself had no interest in, or patience with, what he considered aimless social chatter, and he did not enjoy being with people whom he did not know or care about much.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-208-00.wav: Mostly, he preferred reading or working undisturbed on his own projects.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-208-01.wav: Even after he retired, he was still invited to professional conferences and seminars.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-208-02.wav: It was certainly a different marital pattern than any of the other couples they knew, but it was one they had become accustomed to over the years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-209-00.wav: Then, four years ago, Lily suffered a sudden neurological incident in which she lost consciousness temporarily and had to be hospitalized for a few days.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-209-01.wav: This was eventually diagnosed as a seizure plus a mild stroke.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-209-02.wav: Neurological tests including M R I, E E G, and brain scans indicated some slight brain damage and also some physical weakness on one side.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-209-03.wav: She was placed under medical care and was prescribed anti-seizure medication and physical therapy.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-210-00.wav: The effects of the seizure were neither life threatening nor dramatically disabling, but what Lily has felt most of all is the impact on her short-term memory.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-210-01.wav: It is harder for her to absorb or retain new information, especially new facts.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-210-02.wav: She forgets things easily, sometimes even what she has just said or heard, so conversations may take some repeating or reminding.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-210-03.wav: As a result, her speech and responses are slow, and she feels self-conscious and apologetic about them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-211-00.wav: Their son, who is now almost middle-aged, lives in another state.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-211-01.wav: They have not had a close relationship with him for a long time, but he came to visit Lily when she was in the hospital and he has called his parents more frequently ever since then.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-212-02.wav: He also goes with her for long walks every day, the walks having been recommended by the doctor to try to strengthen the weakened side of her body.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-213-00.wav: Without even discussing it, they now find themselves in a totally new routine with each other, and they spend more time together then they ever did in almost their entire married life.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-213-02.wav: They both seem to recognize that the long-term pattern of their marriage has been irrevocably altered.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-213-03.wav: Once, when Lily mentioned this, Herb simply shrugged and said, It's all right.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-213-04.wav: We all have to do whatever we have to do.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-214-00.wav: Bonnie and Simon have lived in their home for more than forty years, and for most of that time they were probably the most popular couple in the neighborhood.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-214-01.wav: Bonnie was the outstanding cook, hostess, and volunteer who baked cookies for school events, led their daughter's Brownie troop, and served at neighborhood birthday parties.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-214-02.wav: Simon assisted their son's Cub Scout troop, led the boys on hikes, and repaired the neighborhood children's bicycles.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-214-03.wav: Even after all the neighborhood children grew up and moved away, Bonnie and Simon continued doing the same for the next generation.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-215-00.wav: Then, almost ten years ago, Bonnie fell on the driveway outside their home and severely fractured her arm.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-215-01.wav: Emergency surgery was performed to reset the fracture, but the arm did not heal, and it remained weak, painful, and misshapen.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-215-02.wav: The orthopedist suggested a second surgery but first arranged for some further tests, and a scan disclosed the presence of bone cancer.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-216-00.wav: This was the beginning of years of treatment that escalated as the cancer metastasized to the other arm and then to one leg.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-216-01.wav: There was more surgery, followed by radiation and several series of different kinds of chemotherapy, each of which was only temporarily effective.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-216-02.wav: Two years ago, when their children held a fiftieth anniversary party for them, Bonnie was confined to a wheelchair.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-216-03.wav: She had lost her hair due to the chemotherapy, and her grandson gave her a baseball cap that she wore jauntily, visor backward like all the boys did.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-00.wav: Simon retired from his job in an engineering firm and took over responsibility for the household.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-01.wav: The first thing he did was rearrange the rooms for patient care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-02.wav: The family room next to the kitchen was converted into a combination bedroom and sitting room, with a hospital bed for her, a bed for himself, a large television set, and some chairs for visitors.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-03.wav: The upstairs rooms were virtually closed off except to accommodate visiting children or grandchildren.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-04.wav: Simon installed a call button system so Bonnie can summon him if he is in another part of the house.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-217-05.wav: He also purchased a van with special equipment to manage the wheelchair for when he has to take Bonnie to the doctor, the only time now that she leaves the house.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-218-00.wav: Simon has hired someone to do the housecleaning, but he takes care of most of the other chores himself.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-218-01.wav: He looks on it as almost a challenge to his technological skills, and he has organized and computerized all Bonnie's recipes, grocery supplies, and shopping lists.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-218-02.wav: The visiting nurse comes three times a week to monitor and bathe Bonnie and to give her chemotherapy injections.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-218-03.wav: The nurse has also instructed Simon in how to do these things, if necessary, and he has organized a notebook record of Bonnie's illness over the past ten years, including all her medications, treatments, tests, and test results.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-219-01.wav: However, visitors have now become much fewer and do not stay long.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-219-02.wav: Partly this is because Bonnie tires so easily, especially after treatments, but it is also because seeing Bonnie in this condition makes visitors feel too sad or uncomfortable, and there are so few things they can talk about with her now.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-219-03.wav: Their daughter who lives nearby visits several times a week for what she calls mother sitting.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-220-00.wav: Those who know Bonnie marvel at her perseverance, but they are also mystified by her willingness to undergo all these different kinds of treatments, including experimental ones, that cause so many difficult and debilitating side effects.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-220-03.wav: And Simon quietly adds, If that's what Bonnie wants, that's the way it's going to be.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-221-00.wav: Ella and Lewis have been married forty-eight years.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-221-01.wav: He is ten years older than she is but looks even older than that.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-221-02.wav: While she is slim, smooth cheeked, and scarcely graying, he is balding, somewhat stooped, and weary looking.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-221-03.wav: Indeed, there is something not only youthful but almost childlike in the way she smiles and sits quietly with her hands folded in her lap.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-221-04.wav: Meeting Ella for the first time, it seems that there is something not quite right, but it's hard to tell what.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-222-00.wav: When they first met, Ella was the sheltered daughter of a well-to-do family, and Lewis was already a successful practicing attorney.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-222-01.wav: After they married, she became what he calls the unpaid secretary and social partner in his legal practice.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-222-02.wav: She made telephone calls for him, scheduled appointments, kept the office attractive, helped soothe disgruntled or distressed clients, and entertained important local business or political figures.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-224-00.wav: During the first few years of their marriage, Ella suffered several miscarriages, but the doctors were never able to uncover any significant medical reason.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-224-01.wav: Eventually, the couple gave up trying and stopped hoping to have children.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-225-00.wav: It was about a dozen years ago, while Ella was still only in her fifties, that she started experiencing beginning symptoms that the doctors would later term early onset Alzheimer's disease.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-225-01.wav: It started with forgetting people's names and then forgetting who they were or that she even knew them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-225-02.wav: Sometimes she forgot what she wanted to say or had even begun to say.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-226-00.wav: At the beginning, she was embarrassed and tried to hide the forgetfulness or to make excuses, but the lapses soon became too frequent and obvious.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-226-01.wav: Lewis took her to all the specialists who were recommended, which included internists, neurologists, psychiatrists, and gerontologists, and all concurred in the diagnosis of some form of beginning dementia.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-226-02.wav: Ella was prescribed medication that might slow the progression down, but it could not stop or alter the direction of the disease.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-227-00.wav: At first, Ella was extremely upset about what was happening to her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-227-01.wav: In fact, one year on her birthday, when she had blown out the candles on a lavish cake and Lewis asked what she had wished for, she answered, I wished for a new head!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-227-02.wav: But later on, as the symptoms worsened, she actually became less upset, as if she no longer really knew what was happening to her or what it meant.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-228-00.wav: She can now no longer sustain a conversation, make a decision, or answer a question except about what she is specifically doing at this particular moment.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-228-01.wav: She obeys instructions passively, and seems content to sit quietly, especially when Lewis is with her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-229-00.wav: Lewis has hired a housekeeper who also serves as an attendant for Ella when he is not home.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-229-01.wav: On the days he is home, he takes Ella out to lunch, which delights her because she enjoys dressing up and seeing the people and eating different desserts.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-229-02.wav: He says wistfully that she is now almost like the little girl they never had!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-230-00.wav: What concerns him most is not the present but the future.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-230-01.wav: The doctors have told him that, because Ella is comparatively young to be at this stage of Alzheimer's disease, and is still physically healthy, she can live this way for many years; and given his age, it means that she may outlive him by a long time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-230-02.wav: They have no children or close relatives to take responsibility; therefore Lewis has made arrangements with a lawyer friend to serve as legal executor of their estate in case of his own death, and has specified funds and arrangements for Ella's continuing care.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-230-03.wav: He describes this very matter-of-factly, almost in legalese terms, and concludes, I think I've taken care of everything I can.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-231-00.wav: Dora and Mickey have been married fifty-eight years, and they both describe their marriage as strong if not always smooth.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-231-01.wav: He admits to having a short fuse, quick to anger or excitability; while she describes herself as Miss Sunshine who tries to cheer things up and calm things down.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-231-02.wav: She sums up by saying, He's a yeller and I'm a smiler, but by now, we both know exactly what the other one means.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-232-00.wav: They first met during World War two when they lived in the same big city neighborhood, but she was only a teenager at the time and too young to date.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-232-01.wav: He enlisted in the army, and by the time he came home from the war, she had grown into a tall, attractive, almost young woman.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-232-02.wav: Right after her eighteenth birthday, they eloped.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-234-01.wav: There was another younger child, a little boy, who died in infancy of meningitis.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-234-02.wav: They rarely talk about him because, even after all these years, it is still painful for Dora, and Mickey gets upset when he sees her upset.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-00.wav: After they sold the store and retired, they enjoyed their leisure time for only a few years before they both started experiencing health problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-01.wav: Dora developed rheumatoid arthritis, which caused swelling and pain in her fingers, hands, and knees.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-02.wav: One knee became so painful that it was difficult to walk, and she had to undergo knee replacement surgery.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-03.wav: And now one hip has become affected, and the rheumatologist is recommending hip replacement surgery.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-04.wav: Dora ruefully refers to herself as turning into a bionic woman.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-235-05.wav: She is rarely totally pain free, but she doesn't want to take prescribed pain medication too much or too often because she becomes sleepy or disoriented.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-236-01.wav: Since then, Mickey has been under regular medical care, takes medication, and always carries nitroglycerine pills for emergencies.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-236-02.wav: He has continued to experience some minor incidents, and the doctor has cautioned that he must try to learn to take things more easily and calmly if he is to avoid a worse angina attack in the future.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-236-03.wav: Mickey finds this advice bitterly amusing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-236-07.wav: Should I make my life over?
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-237-00.wav: Dora and Mickey are both aware of, and worried about, each other's health problems, and they try to protect one another by being secretive or silent about their own problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-237-01.wav: Because he doesn't want to upset her, Mickey tries not to complain about any feelings of tiredness or weakness, and often assures her that he is all right even when he really is not.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-237-02.wav: And because she doesn't want to upset him, Dora tries not to complain about her own pain, and so she too sometimes lies about how she is feeling.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-237-03.wav: Yet they know each other so well that, deep down, they can usually tell when the other one is suffering, even if there is nothing they can do about it.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-238.wav: Their daughter is extremely concerned but also exasperated by her parents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-239-00.wav: She has urged them to stop playing games with each other and being so protective, to be more honest about their pains and their needs.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-239-01.wav: Dora and Mickey appreciate her concern but continue to ignore her advice.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-241-00.wav: Bess is a small woman, neat and graying, earnest and soft-spoken; Mel is also short, but muscular, and gives the impression of being a man of few words, or at least one who prefers to say few words.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-241-01.wav: Bess describes the two of them without apology or complaint, as ordinary people who had ordinary lives.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-241-02.wav: She says that they never did anything important or special, they just always tried to be good people.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-241-03.wav: One thing they are both proud of is that the two of them, who barely finished high school themselves, were able to ensure that both of their children went to college and had more opportunities than they had.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-242-00.wav: Before his retirement, Mel worked as a dispatcher for a long-distance trucking company, a position he had moved up to after several years of on-the-road driving.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-242-01.wav: He appreciated the better salary and regular hours of the new position, but he actually missed some of the freedom he had enjoyed being on the road on his own.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-242-02.wav: On the other hand, Bess was greatly relieved by his office job because it meant he was safer and also more available.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-243-00.wav: Throughout most of her adult years, Bess has had high blood pressure and has taken medication to keep it under control.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-243-01.wav: Her mother also suffered from serious high blood pressure and eventually died of a resulting stroke so Bess has been conscientious about monitoring her diet, salt intake, and medication.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-243-03.wav: She seems to have recovered completely as far as symptoms indicate; but what she does feel and worry about is the unnerving fear of a recurring stroke.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-244-00.wav: On the other hand, Mel's health was remarkable because it was so unremarkable.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-244-01.wav: He never got sick, never had any complaints, hardly ever went to see doctors, didn't take any regularly prescribed medication, and boasted of his cast iron stomach that digested anything he ate or drank.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-244-02.wav: He never paid any attention to his health, and therefore neither did she.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-245-00.wav: Two years ago, just about the time of his eightieth birthday, Mel began complaining of fatigue, which was out of character for him.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-245-01.wav: He also noticed an unusual swelling of his legs.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-245-02.wav: He dismissed these symptoms and insisted they would go away, but then he experienced some urinary bleeding.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-245-03.wav: At this point, Bess and their children insisted that he see a doctor.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-245-04.wav: After a number of examinations and procedures, it was learned that he had a tumor on one of his kidneys, and a biopsy showed it to be malignant.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-246-00.wav: Mel's general health was otherwise good, so surgery was performed to remove the diseased kidney.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-246-01.wav: The surgery was successful, but the recuperation was slow, and his previous secure feeling of strength never completely returned.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-246-02.wav: He now has to maintain a strict diet, monitor fluid intakes carefully, take frequent blood tests, rest more at home, and see his doctor regularly.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-247-00.wav: Bess has been as conscientious in taking care of Mel's health as she has always been with her own.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-247-01.wav: She worries about whether he is eating or sleeping enough; she measures and monitors all his liquids; she watches to see that he takes his medications and follows the doctor's instructions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-247-02.wav: He complains that she's making too much of a fuss, but nevertheless he has been an accepting, if unhappy, patient.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-248-00.wav: They are both trying hard but still struggling with these new circumstances while settling into a reciprocal routine.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-248-01.wav: Bess knows that she is no longer the exclusive or primary patient in the family and can no longer rely unquestioningly on her husband to take care of her.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-248-03.wav: It is as if they are both trying to figure out how much help they can or should give to each other, and also how much help they can or should expect to receive from each other.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-248-04.wav: Even their adult children have felt this change because they now worry about both of their parents, not just one of them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-250-00.wav: They are both still tall and handsome people, although illness and weight loss have sharpened Bert's features and made Claire look frail.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-250-01.wav: There is still a kind of affectionate bantering between them, and occasional flashes of humor from Bert who tries to keep their conversations as light as possible.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-251-00.wav: Both of them agree that those first fifty years of marriage were happy and successful, and any problems they recall now seem trivial, almost amusing.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-251-01.wav: There were the efforts and exasperations of raising four sons, all of them now tall, strapping men.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-251-02.wav: There were the vociferous political arguments between a conservative Bert and a liberal Claire at every election their votes canceled each other out.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-251-03.wav: And there was the nuisance for Claire, as the only female in a household of five men, of never finding the toilet seat down!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-252-00.wav: They always had a close and easy relationship with their sons and daughters-in-law, and the four brothers also got along well with one another.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-252-01.wav: In fact, for years, there was a family tradition of once each month celebrating together all the birthdays or anniversaries or other special events that occurred during that month.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-252-02.wav: But during these past few years, these celebrations have become subdued since both Claire and Bert have been suffering from worsening heart problems.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-253-00.wav: Bert has had episodes of heart stoppages that had to be treated with timely application of a defibrillator.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-253-01.wav: He has already undergone angiogram and angioplasty procedures; and, so far, the doctors are trying to treat him with different medications before resorting to bypass surgery.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-253-02.wav: Claire has had two cardiac surgeries, attempting to replace a leaking heart valve.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-253-03.wav: The operations have not been completely successful, and the doctors are reluctant to risk further surgery because of her present condition.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-255-00.wav: Claire confides, out of his earshot, that his cooking is terrible, and also that for someone with such mechanical aptitude for machinery, he seems to have surprising difficulty with the buttons on the dishwasher or washing machine!
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-255-01.wav: But to him, she always expresses appreciation for whatever he does, even when they both know it was not necessarily done well.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-256-01.wav: Mostly, they try to take care of whatever they can at home, rest a lot, watch television, and still argue about politics.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-257-00.wav: Fortunately, so far, their individual episodes of acute weakness or pain have not occurred at the same time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-257-01.wav: They seem to take turns being ill, so they also take turns taking care of each other when that happens.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-258-00.wav: Claire says that she is the most grateful not so much for what Bert does or tries to do, but just for the fact that he is there.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-258-01.wav: And Bert agrees, saying that it's bad enough being sick, but at least they're not sick alone.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-259-00.wav: Merle and Jim have been married forty-eight years.

./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-262-00.wav: About four years ago, Jim suffered a major stroke that required months of hospitalization and rehabilitation at various veterans facilities.
./datasets/nancy/audio/HAW-262-01.wav: He was paralyzed on one side, and his speech was also affected but never his mind, as he is quick to point out.

./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-13.wav: Arthur Lessac is the pioneer who developed the kinesensic approach to the use and training of the human voice.
./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-14.wav: Although he is now ninety-nine years old, Arthur Lessac is still actively teaching, and still the only widely acknowledged expert in the kinesensic methods of voice instruction.

./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-19.wav: Lessac Technologies has developed a new way of synthesizing human speech which enables a computer to automatically produce fully expressive prosodic human speech from plain text input.
./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-20.wav: David A Evans, born nineteen forty eight in Saint Louis, is the president, CEO and chief scientist of JustSystems Evans Research Inc.

./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-22.wav: Doctor Evans attended Stanford University, receiving his Ph D in Computational Linguistics there in nineteen eighty two.
./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-23.wav: Evans was on the faculty of Carnegie Mellon University from nineteen eighty three until nineteen ninety six, and founded their Computational Linguistics Program and Laboratory for Computational Linguistics.
./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-24.wav: In nineteen ninety three, the research of David Evans was spun-out from Carnegie-mellon, as Claritech.
./datasets/nancy/audio/LTI-25.wav: Claritech became a research and development subsidiary of JustSystems and its name was changed to Clairvoyance Corporation in nineteen ninety six, before becoming JustSystems Evans Research Inc in two thousand and seven.

./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-00.wa: Kids thinking abilities are also undergoing a transformation.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-01.wa: During the middle-school years, they begin to be able to see more than one side of an issue.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-02.wa: They can question the reasons behind rules and point out contradictions between what parents say and what parents do.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-03.wa: In addition, their social world is expanding.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-04.wa: Now there are more friends, more teachers, more school and community activities to engage their interest and take up their time.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0002-05.wa: That means other people, places, and experiences that they're having away from home take on a larger role in shaping their thoughts and decisions.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0003-00.wa: All of this means that when children reach the middle-school years, parent relationships with them are not the same as they used to be.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0003-01.wa: Conflict increases, closeness decreases, and frustration can often result.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0003-02.wa: All of these changes point to one important and undeniable fact: the middle-school years are a pivotal stage in the development of human beings.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0004-00.wa: The choices that middle-school students make and the experiences they have during these years will shape the course of their development through adolescence and into adulthood, and will greatly affect the kind of people they become.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0004-01.wa: It is during this time of tremendous transition that young people need us, as caring parents, more than ever to support and guide them through the maze of changes and decisions they face.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0004-02.wa: In matters of school, friendship, health, and happiness, the children who do the best are the ones who have good relationships with their parents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0005-00.wa: It sounds so simple, doesn't it?
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0005-01.wa: To raise kids through the trying preteen years, parents just need to continue to love them, supervise them, and talk to them.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0005-03.wa: Many parents don't know how or don't take time to talk with their middle-school children about important issues, and many kids feel unable to communicate with their parents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0005-04.wa: Data from large-scale national surveys by the Search Institute reveal that only one out of four youth report that their parents are approachable and available when they want to talk.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0006-00.wa: The results of this disconnect are evident in the numbers of kids involved in alcohol and drugs, violence, and other unhealthy behaviors.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0010-00.wa: The surprising result of this research was that the questions kids want to ask their parents are mostly about relationships, and some of the most important relationship issues they want to talk about are within the family.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0010-01.wa: The questions largely fell into twelve broad categories.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0010-02.wa: For example, more than one hundred questions were about the parent-child relationship, including questions about the child's autonomy and budding independence, their parent's love for them, as well as questions about support, trust, and conflict.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0010-03.wa: There were almost as many questions about the parent's childhood, life experience, and life perspective.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0010-04.wa: There were nearly fifty questions about the extended family.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0013-00.wa: In writing this book we have drawn on our own experiences and many years of reading and teaching about adolescence, and parenting.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0013-01.wa: While our insights and ideas represent a melding of many influences, from experiential to scholarly, we want to acknowledge several authors whose works have been particularly influential.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0013-02.wa: They are Adele Faber, Grace Llewellyn, Elaine Mazlish, Alex Packer, and Laurence Steinberg.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0013-03.wa: Their books are included in the Selected Readings and Resources section at the back of this book.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-00.wa: Families, like ice cream, come in many different flavors, all of them delicious.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-01.wa: Some of you reading this book may be part of a traditional family, with a mom, a dad, and one or more children, who hope to find ways to spend quality time together.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-02.wa: Some of you may be single moms or dads, who share custody and need to make the most of the time you spend with your child.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-03.wa: Some of you may be single moms or dads handling the parenting job alone, who have just enough energy left at the end of a busy week to watch a movie.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-04.wa: Some may be stepparents or unmarried partners of parents with preteens, who are looking for a way to be supportive.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-05.wa: Some of you may be gay or lesbian parents, with or without a partner, who may or may not be biologically related to the child you are raising together.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-06.wa: Some of you may be adoptive parents, who do not know much about the biological parents of your child.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-07.wa: Some of you may be foster parents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0014-08.wa: Some of you may be aunts, uncles, youth group leaders, or school counselors, who are looking for ways to interact more effectively with the middle-school children and their families that you care about.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0015-00.wa: Based on the research, this book is directed to families that include middle-school children.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0015-01.wa: We use various terms for this group of younger people, including kids, middle-school children, middle schoolers, and middlers.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0015-02.wa: We also use teens, preteens, young adolescents, and pre-adolescents.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0015-03.wa: All of these are meant to refer to people moving through that critical transitional stage between childhood and high school, roughly between ten and fourteen years old.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0016-00.wa: For simplicity's sake, we refer to one parent and one child when we discuss the topics in this book, and we alternate between the gender pronouns.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0016-03.wa: Some of the movies are suitable for younger children as well.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0016-04.wa: We provide a cautionary summary of the language, sexual content, drug or alcohol activity, and violence in each movie so that you can decide if it is appropriate for all the children you want to include in your movie nights.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-00.wa: Some of the characters in the movies we've selected are older than middle schoolers, but we believe all the movies will be interesting and relevant to this age group as well as to adults.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-01.wa: We've made a concerted effort, given the available resources, to make this book, the movies, and other activities inviting to a broad range of people and experiences.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-02.wa: For example, we sought out movies that reflect some of the ethnic diversity of people living in the United States, although finding appropriate films with the variety we wanted was challenging.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-03.wa: Middle class, working class, and poor families; urban, suburban, and rural settings are all represented.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-04.wa: The protagonists are both boys and girls; in the case of platonic friendships, we suggest two movies to address differences related to gender.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-05.wa: Films that portray populations such as family members with disabilities or families with gay or lesbian parents or offspring are still rare and are therefore not included.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0017-06.wa: We hope more movies that reflect the incredible diversity of our country will become available in the near future so that a broader range of families can easily see themselves reflected in a book such as this.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0018-00.wa: What Kids REALLY Want to Ask is a guidebook, organized around watching movies together for the purpose of sparking meaningful conversations between you and the preteen in your life.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0018-02.wa: Each chapter explores one theme revealed through the research with middle-school students.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0018-03.wa: Issues related to the family are addressed in the first six chapters, and broader relationship and life issues are covered in the last six.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0018-04.wa: For each theme, we have identified one or two movies that reflect the kinds of questions kids seem to have about that topic.
./datasets/nancy/audio/WKRWTA-0018-05.wa: The chapters, themes, and movies are listed below.
